prior_works.title: Individual Preference Stability in Clustering
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the IP-stability notion, proved 1-IP feasibility is NP-hard, and provided only an O(n)-IP existence guarantee—establishing the central question that this paper resolves by proving an O(1) existence and algorithm.

prior_works.title: Approximation Algorithms for the Multiway Cut Problem
prior_works.authors: Gruia Calinescu, Howard Karloff, Yuval Rabani
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The CKR randomized partition with Lipschitz separation (Pr[separation] ≤ O(d(u,v)/Δ)) underpins the paper’s construction of clusterings that control per-point average in- vs. out-of-cluster distances, enabling a constant-factor IP guarantee.

prior_works.title: A Tight Bound on Approximating Arbitrary Metrics by Tree Metrics
prior_works.authors: Jittat Fakcharoenphol, Satish Rao, Kunal Talwar
prior_works.role: Hierarchical random partitions and tree embeddings
prior_works.relationship_sentence: FRT’s multiscale random hierarchies inform the paper’s multi-scale reasoning about average distances and efficient implementation of decompositions that yield IP-stable clusterings in general metrics.

prior_works.title: On Approximating Metric Spaces by Tree Metrics
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Bartal’s framework for random tree/partition embeddings is a conceptual and technical precursor to the decomposition methods adapted here to bound separation probabilities and average-distance ratios per point.

prior_works.title: Bounded Geometries, Fractals, and Low-Distortion Embeddings
prior_works.authors: Anupam Gupta, Robert Krauthgamer, James R. Lee
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Padded decomposition ideas provide the per-ball containment/probabilistic guarantees needed to argue that most local neighborhoods of a point remain intact, which directly supports constant IP-stability bounds.

prior_works.title: Are Stable Instances Easy?
prior_works.role: Stability framework for clustering beyond worst-case
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established the analytical paradigm that structural stability properties can yield stronger algorithmic guarantees; this perspective influenced formulating and proving existence/algorithms under IP-style per-point stability.

prior_works.title: Fair Clustering Through Fairlets
prior_works.authors: Flavio Chierichetti, Ravi Kumar, Silvio Lattanzi, Sergei Vassilvitskii
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided the fairness motivation and precedent for individual-level guarantees in clustering, informing the design and interpretation of IP-stability as a per-point fairness/stability criterion.

synthesis_narrative:
The core contribution—proving that every metric admits an O(1)-IP-stable clustering and giving an efficient algorithm—builds directly on the problem formulation and open gap left by Ahmadi et al. (ICML’22), who introduced IP stability, showed 1-IP feasibility is NP-hard, and could only guarantee O(n)-IP stability. To close this, the authors leverage classical randomized metric partitioning. The CKR multiway-cut rounding provides a Lipschitz separation guarantee that the probability a pair is cut scales with their distance. Combined with Bartal’s and FRT’s probabilistic tree embeddings and hierarchical decompositions, this enables a multi-scale construction where, for each point, most of its local neighborhood remains within its cluster with high probability, keeping its average intra-cluster distance within a constant factor of its average distance to other clusters.

Gupta–Krauthgamer–Lee’s padded decomposition perspective further supplies per-ball containment guarantees essential for bounding per-point losses when partitioning at appropriate scales, a key step in achieving constant factors in general metrics. Conceptually, the work is situated within the broader stability literature (Bilu–Linial), adopting the insight that structural stability notions can yield qualitatively stronger guarantees than worst-case approximations. Finally, the fairness-in-clustering line (Chierichetti et al.) motivates per-point guarantees and helps interpret IP-stability as an individual-level fairness/stability constraint. Together, these works provide both the formal objective and the decomposition toolkit that make the constant-factor existence and algorithms possible, and they extend naturally to max/min distance variants by requiring stronger per-ball containment properties at selected scales.
